title: 115_s1776
content: The "Agricultural Energy Programs Reauthorization Act of 2017" may also be referred to as the Act. It includes a section on the Biobased Markets Program. Section 9002 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include renewable chemicals in the biobased products labeling program. The Secretary will provide education and outreach to stakeholders. Manufacturers of renewable chemicals and biobased products will be classified under specific NAICS codes. The amendment includes developing NAICS codes for renewable chemicals and biobased products manufacturers. It also increases funding to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. The amendment increases funding to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2019 through 2023 and includes products produced from biologically captured and reused carbon. SEC. 3. BIOREFINERY, RENEWABLE CHEMICAL, AND BIOBASED PRODUCT MANUFACTURING ASSISTANCE. Section 9003 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to provide mandatory funding of $75,000,000 for loan guarantees for renewable chemical or biobased product technologies in biorefineries until 2023. SEC. 4. The Bioenergy Program for Advanced Biofuels is amended to allocate $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2023. SEC. 5. The Rural Energy for America Program is also updated. The definition of a renewable energy system is expanded to include distribution components and ancillary infrastructure. Funding for renewable energy programs is also amended. The Investment Act of 2002 is amended to allocate $150,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2018 through 2023. Additionally, funding for renewable energy programs is increased to $50,000,000 annually for the same period. Not more than 30% of the funds can be used for specific renewable energy forms or energy efficiency technologies. SEC. 6. Biomass research and development funding is increased to $20,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2019 through 2023. SEC. 7. Feedstock flexibility program for bioenergy producers is extended until 2023. SEC. 8. Biofuels and biobased product feedstock program is updated for wildland fire protection. Section 9011 of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include a biofuels and biobased product feedstock and wildland fire protection program. This involves redesignating paragraphs and updating certain clauses within the program. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to include a Biofuels and Biobased Product Feedstock and Wildland Fire Protection Program. This involves updating clauses and redesignating paragraphs within the program. The Biofuels and Biobased Product Feedstock and Wildland Fire Protection Program is updated by amending the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. This includes redesignating paragraphs and updating clauses within the program. The Biofuels and Biobased Product Feedstock and Wildland Fire Protection Program is amended by updating subsections (c) and (d) of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. This involves changing references from "BCAP" to "program" and making adjustments to various paragraphs within the program. The Biofuels and Biobased Product Feedstock and Wildland Fire Protection Program is amended by updating subsections (c) and (d) of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. Changes include redesignating paragraphs, providing payments for hazardous woody fuel reduction projects, and considering project eligibility for transportation cost coverage. The Secretary will consider projects in wildland areas at risk from wildfire or in need of restoration, prioritizing those that benefit human life and structures in the wildland-urban interface and protect municipal water supplies. Producers receiving payments must limit biomass collection for environmental benefit. In order to receive payment, producers must leave uncollected and unharvested at least 30 percent of woody eligible material. The Secretary will allocate $70,000,000 annually from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for fiscal years 2019 through 2023 to carry out this program. The Secretary will allocate $70,000,000 annually from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for fiscal years 2019 through 2023 to carry out transportation payments for hazardous woody fuel reduction projects. Additionally, $20,000,000 is authorized for discretionary funding for the same period. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 is amended to extend the Community Wood Energy Program until 2023. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2018.
